verses.text: Then Jonah prayed to the LORD his God from inside the fish,
verses.comment: Jonah's prayer marks a turn to God in distress. The context emphasizes turning to God even from seemingly impossible situations, a theme echoed throughout Scripture (e.g., Daniel in the lions' den, Psalm 130).

verses.text: and he said, 'I called out to the LORD in my distress, and he answered me. From the belly of Sheol I cried out, and you heard my voice.'
verses.comment: Jonah describes his location as the 'belly of Sheol,' a term often meaning 'the place of the dead.' This foreshadows Christ’s descent into death (see Matthew 12:40), and prefigures deliverance through resurrection. The language of prayer and being heard underscores the power of intercessory prayer.

verses.text: You cast me into the deep, into the heart of the seas, and the floods surrounded me; all your waves and your breakers washed over me.
verses.comment: Jonah recognizes God’s sovereignty in his trial—'You cast me.' This highlights God’s providence and use of means for His purpose, showing a depth of trust even in hardship. The sea, often associated with chaos, is subject to God's command.

verses.text: And I said, ‘I have been driven away from your sight; yet I will look again toward your holy temple.’
verses.comment: Jonah feels exiled but expresses hope by turning towards the temple, the earthly dwelling of God. This points to the importance of sacred spaces and ordained worship. The temple precursors New Testament teaching about God's dwelling among His people (see John 2:19-21).

verses.text: The waters closed in over me to take my life; the deep surrounded me; weeds were wrapped around my head
verses.comment: The imagery of drowning intensifies the sense of death and helplessness, connecting to the Psalms where the righteous cry for deliverance. Early Christian writers often saw in this a symbol of baptism—passing through death to new life.

verses.text: At the roots of the mountains I went down to the land whose bars closed upon me forever; yet you brought up my life from the pit, O LORD my God.
verses.comment: Jonah depicts utter hopelessness but then God's miraculous intervention—lifting him from 'the pit.' This line foreshadows the resurrection, referenced in Peter’s sermon (Acts 2:31).

verses.text: When my life was fainting away, I remembered the LORD, and my prayer came to you, into your holy temple.
verses.comment: Jonah’s prayer ascending to the temple highlights the value of intercessory prayer and the role of priests and the temple in mediating these prayers (see Revelation 5:8).

verses.text: Those who regard worthless idols forsake their loyal love.
verses.comment: Jonah condemns idolatry, contrasting loyalty to God with empty devotion. This verse reminds us that faithfulness to God includes rejecting false teaching and clinging to the fullness of truth (see 1 Thessalonians 1:9).

verses.text: But I, with a voice of thanksgiving, will sacrifice to you; what I have vowed I will fulfill. Salvation belongs to the LORD!'
verses.comment: Jonah responds with worship and sacrifice, fulfilling vows. The reference to sacrifice links to the importance of liturgical worship and the continuation of offering praises to God through appointed means. Salvation as God's gift prepares the way for Christ’s redemptive work.

verses.text: And the LORD commanded the fish, and it vomited Jonah onto the dry land.
verses.comment: God's command to the fish demonstrates His sovereignty over creation. Jonah’s emergence from the fish after three days is a prophetic type pointing directly to Christ’s resurrection on the third day (see Matthew 12:40), affirming God’s plan of salvation accomplished through mighty works.
